page.title: 01THE HILLS
page.content: The first thing we noticed was that the area was generally boggy. This was due to the water from the hills running down and lying on areas of shallow gradience. In the area there are nine hilltops. The highest being Dearlaw at a height of six hundred and twenty nine feet. The main burn in the area is the Glengaber with seven tributaries. The source of the Glengaber runs from Redsike head in the north west corner of the map of the area. The land is desolate with not a house in sight and shows no signs of being cultivated or used for grazing. There are many peat hags in the area and an abundance of Spagnhem moss and several other Wetland grasses. We found evidence of affected grass which might have been caused by acid rain or some other chemical at some time. The blades of grass in some
